pullRequest.body:
We prove that a disjoint filter and ideal in a bounded distributive lattice can always be separated by a prime ideal. This is a step towards establishing Stone duality (currently in development here: https://github.com/samvang/StoneDualityInLean/)

- [x] depends on: #12651 (ideals of sets are stable under directed unions and chains)
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#12651~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

:v: samvang can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9119426784/job/25074763057)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9119426784/job/25074762600)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9119426784/job/25074762853)

Your proof is very nicely commented! It is slightly long for a typical Mathlib proof but there are no obvious intermediate results that I can suggest splitting off. So I think with a few tricks to achieve more powerful tactics this is good to go.

bors d+

Your proof is very nicely commented! It is slightly long for a typical Mathlib proof but there are no obvious intermediate results that I can suggest splitting off. So I think with a few tricks to achieve more powerful tactics this is good to go.

bors d+
couldn't you define S as a `Set (Ideal α)`? That would save some coercions and `Jset` below.

I tried this quite seriously several times and would have indeed liked the definition to look like that. Unfortunately I don't see how to do it at the moment, for the following reason. In the proof of `chainub` a bit below, I need at some point to take a union of a chain of ideals in `S`. Mathlib has a complete lattice instance on `Ideal α`, so I can take the `sSup` instead of the `sUnion`, but the supremum of a set of ideals is not equal to a union in general. It is only a union in this case, because we are taking the supremum of a chain. So, if one wanted to make this work, it would require first proving (somewhere else) that `sSup` of a chain of ideals is a union. I'm not sure this is worthwhile.
For standard rings, sSup of a chain of ideals is a union, and this is very useful for proving the existence of maximal ideals.
I would personally be in favor of implementing that for lattice ideals as well but I would imagine it is a separate PR.
Does `⟨⟨Jidl, IJ : I ≤ J, JF⟩, ⟨_, Jmax⟩⟩ := hJ` work?
It works to replace `obtain` with `let`. Is that preferable? I did that for now.
some people use `obtain`, other use `rcases`, I don't think it matters too much.

IJ₁ is used only here, couldn't you just insert the proof at this point?
Same for IJ₂ below, and some other functions that you introduce.
Indeed, I'll try. Thanks

Does the following work ?
```
 have J₁S : ↑J₁ ∉ S := fun h => J₁J (Jmax J₁ h le_sup_left)
 have J₂S : ↑J₂ ∉ S := fun h => J₂J (Jmax J₂ h le_sup_left)
```

It works with type annotation: `fun h => J₁J (Jmax J₁ h (le_sup_left : J ≤ J₁))`
I changed it into that.

I don't know whether that's really preferred, I try myself not to add too many intermediate lemmas (whose names have to be remembered), especially if they're only use once and their proofs is not too long.
You could probably do `apply not_not_intro JF`
This did not work for me, the goal at this point is a₁ ⊓ a₂ ∉ J which is not of the required form ¬ ¬ p.
This was just a suggestion to avoid proving an intermediate lemma (and have a more backwards-type proof). No problem besides that.
I have understood that non terminal `simp` should be `simp only`. If needed, `simp?` will tell you what happens.
Oops, indeed, thanks.
Since `PFilter` and `Ideal` are extended by changing the preorder relation, is the “dual” result worth being stated?

I'm not sure exactly what mathematical statement you mean? "If F and I are disjoint there exists a prime filter containing G and disjoint from I"? Yes, mathematically this is trivial to derive from what I proved, but it seems that "prime filter" for a distributive lattice has not been defined yet. (Of course it should! But I'm trying to keep the PR minimal.)
So you answered my question mathematically, the rest — if interesting — can be indicated as a TODO in that file, so that if somebody needs it, they will find the remark and maybe find it helpful.

You should be able to simplify this a bit with the `choose` tactic. From the top of my head:
```suggestion
  choose Jset hJ using zorn_subset_nonempty S chainub I IinS
```
Unfortunately it looks like `choose` doesn't support the `rcases`-like destructor syntax so you can't also write
```lean
  choose Jset ⟨⟨Jidl, IJ, JF⟩, ⟨_, Jmax⟩⟩ using zorn_subset_nonempty S chainub I IinS
```

Since you don't actually prove that the elements of `S` are proper:
```suggestion
  -- Let S be the set of (proper) ideals containing I and disjoint from F
```
The word "proper" shouldn't be in this comment at all, I accidentally left it there from an earlier version. Thanks

Oh wait, I'm a silly goose. `rcases`/`obtain` can do this directly since we're making a `Prop`!
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨Jset, ⟨Jidl, IJ, JF⟩, ⟨_, Jmax⟩⟩ := zorn_subset_nonempty S chainub I IinS
```
Great.

Writing `by refine` is sometimes a trick to change the order of elaboration, but doesn't seem to do anything here:
```suggestion
  have J₁J : ↑J₁ ≠ Jset := ne_of_mem_of_not_mem' a₁J₁ ha₁
  have J₂J : ↑J₂ ≠ Jset := ne_of_mem_of_not_mem' a₂J₂ ha₂
```

With `contrapose` you can go from `(hP : P) ⊢ ¬Q` to `(hQ : Q) ⊢ ¬ P` in one tactic.
```suggestion
  contrapose! JF with ha₁a₂
  rw [Set.not_disjoint_iff]
  use b ⊔ (a₁ ⊓ a₂)
  exact ⟨ba₁a₂F, sup_mem bJ ha₁a₂⟩
```
Ah great, this is what I was looking for!

You have commented this proof quite nicely but at this point it's slightly too literal with the actual code. I wouldn't include these comments, or perhaps shorten them to a single sentence explaining why this `ineq` will be useful.
```suggestion
```
Thanks, I agree, I now reformulated it to emphasize the fact that this is where distributivity is used (as, mathematically speaking, this is the important point in the proof)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Mathlib/Order/PrimeSeparator): prime ideal separator in a bounded distributive lattice
